description: Since 1851, many remarkable black men and women did not receive obituaries in The New York Times. This month, with Overlooked, were adding their stories to our archives.

title: At Sundance, a Glorious Diversity of Voices Breaks Through
description: PARK CITY, Utah  A runaway bride, wildly rambunctious women and two quietly resolute girls  the Sundance Film Festival is one movie celebration where the so-called second sex consistently comes out on top. Now in its 36th year, the festival has long made room for female filmmakers even when there werent all that many. In 1985, its inaugural year, it presented 85 movies, 10 from female directors, about half non-Americans like Lina Wertmller, one of the few such filmmakers on anyones radar back then. Of this years 128 features, nearly half are from women. (The festival ends Sunday.)

description: Senator Chuck Schumer tells us about one way he represents New York  through his culinary offerings.

title: Jack Burns, a Comic Force on Camera and Off, Is Dead at 86
description: Jack Burns, who found fame as the hilariously pompous half of Burns and Schreiber, one of the best-known comedy teams of the 1960s and 70s, then made another mark as a television writer, died on Jan. 27  in Toluca Lake, Calif. He was 86.

title: Del Pitt Feldman, Who Made Crocheting Hip, Is Dead at 90
description: Del Pitt Feldman, whose crocheted designs embraced a homegrown technique that had been relegated to potholders and simple scarves and helped redefine it as a respected medium for fashion and art, died on Jan. 14 in Mechanicsburg, Pa. She was 90.

title: D.N.C. Rules Change for Nevada Debate Could Open Door for Bloomberg
description: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa  The Democratic National Committee has opened the door to allowing former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York to participate in the presidential debate it will sponsor in Nevada next month, a change from its practice that demanded candidates demonstrate grass-roots fund-raising support.

title: Aretha Franklins Estate Still Unsettled as Executor Resigns
description: A year and a half after the death of Aretha Franklin, her tumultuous estate has again been thrust into confusion with the pending resignation of the singers niece as executor  a position she had accepted shortly after Franklins death with the full support of the singers four sons.

title: Bloomberg Fueled His Campaign With $200 Million From His Own Fortune
description: DES MOINES  Michael R. Bloomberg put more than $200 million of his personal fortune into his presidential campaign by the end of December, with the overwhelming bulk of that sum going to a mammoth advertising campaign on television and online, according to Mr. Bloombergs first campaign finance disclosure with the Federal Election Commission.

title: Whats Impeachable? Theyll Know It When They See It
description: After more than a week of statements, petitions, arguments and questions, we asked Michelle Cottle, an editorial board member whos been chronicling President Trumps impeachment trial for Opinion each day from Capitol Hill, to offer some much-needed clarity. Below are Ms. Cottles responses to a selection of questions from readers about the proceedings. They have been edited for length and clarity.  Rachel L. Harris and Lisa Tarchak, senior editorial assistants

title: From Armed Struggle to Peaceful Protest, a Road Still to Travel

title: Trump Administration Adds Six Countries to Travel Ban
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Friday added six countries to his list of nations facing stringent travel restrictions, a move that will virtually block immigration from Africas most populous nation, Nigeria, and from Myanmar, where the Muslim minority is fleeing genocide.

title: Neanderthal Genes Hint at Much Earlier Human Migration From Africa
description: In recent years, millions of people have been astonished, even thrilled, to learn from those popular genetic tests that their DNA is laced with Neanderthal genes.

title: Alexander Says Convicting Trump Would Pour Gasoline on Cultural Fires
description: WASHINGTON  As he weighed the evidence against President Trump, Senator Lamar Alexander reached an unavoidable conclusion: Mr. Trump had done what he was accused of, pressuring a foreign power to investigate his political rival. But however inappropriate his conduct, another conviction overrode the first: Americans would not tolerate the Senate stepping in to substitute its own judgment for that of the voters fewer than 10 months before the next election.

title: Dancer Tries to Quell West Side Story Controversy: I Am Not a Victim
description: In the weeks leading up to the opening of the Broadway revival of West Side Story, a small contingent of protesters and an online petition have called for the removal of a prominent cast member, Amar Ramasar, who was at one point fired from New York City Ballet after he shared sexually explicit photos of another dancer.

description: The classic Italian dish bollito misto is no stranger to strong opinions.

title: Louis Nirenberg, One of the Great Mathematicians, Dies at 94

title: Why Its So Hard to Make an Endowment More Socially Responsible

The school pledged, among many other things, to disclose its endowment holdings and initiate a communitywide discussion about whether those investments matched its values and commitment to the environment.

title: Adolphe Binder Wont Return to Pina Bausch Company
description: Adolphe Binder, who was dismissed as director of Tanztheater Wuppertal in July 2018 and has been legally contesting the decision, has chosen not to pursue returning to the company, she said in a statement on Friday. Ms. Binder wrote, I have decided with a heavy heart to waive the artistic direction of Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch in the future and to conclude a court resolution.

title: More of Collectors Dutch and British Objects to Go to Museums
description: In a modest brick apartment house on Staten Island, the antiques collector George Way crammed British and Dutch furniture and art to the ceiling, scarcely leaving circulation routes between 17th-century armchairs and old master portraits of noblewomen. Part of his collection is now going on view in the hands of new institutional owners, with wall texts paying tribute to Mr. Way, who died in June, at 69.

title: Capital in Trump Mideast Plan Makes a Joke of Palestinian Aspirations
description: ABU DIS, West Bank  Like a monument to dashed hopes, an unfinished Palestinian parliament building stands derelict on a ridge in Abu Dis, an unimposing West Bank suburb of Jerusalem that the Trump administration has proposed as the capital of a future Palestinian state.

title: Your Credit Card Benefits Just Got Cut. What Do You Do?

title: Hester Diamond, Passionate Art Collector, Is Dead at 91

description: LONDON  To the recorded peals of Big Ben and the gentle fluttering of Union Jacks, Britain bade farewell to the European Union at 11 p.m. on Friday, severing ties to the worlds largest trading bloc after nearly half a century and embarking on an uncertain future as a midsize economy off the coast of Europe.

title: Battle Lines Quickly Form Over Radical Property Tax Proposal
description: On a stretch of 11th Street in Park Slope, Brooklyn, two houses  one a modest two-family, and the other a three-bedroom clapboard home  could be Exhibits A and B in why New York City is now considering a sweeping proposal to overhaul its property tax system.
